refined_goal: Build Hypermedia Retrofit: a reversible API composition platform that turns Retrofit interfaces into a running Spring Boot micro-gateway with a zero-code, Tabler/AdminLTE-driven operations UI. We repurpose Retrofit’s annotation DSL (@GET, @POST, @Path, @Query) as the single source of truth for contracts, and compile it into: 1) a Spring WebFlux proxy/aggregator with policy hooks, and 2) a live, skinnable dashboard that wires forms, tables, and charts directly from signatures. Success criteria: generate a working dashboard for 3+ external REST APIs in under 15 minutes; add new endpoints with only a Retrofit interface and see UI auto-appear; p95 end-to-end overhead < 2 ms vs raw upstream; role-based auth and rate limits declaratively applied. Why it matters: it collapses client SDKs, gateway config, and admin UI into one declarative contract, radically shrinking integration and operations time while remaining tech-agnostic and portable.
repository_synergy:
THE INSIGHT: Href and src attributes are already a graph of intent; Retrofit annotations are already a compact protocol language. Marry them, and you get a hypermedia circuit designer: HTML anchors become declarative edges to Retrofit-defined operations, while Spring Boot provides the runtime fabric that executes those circuits with production-grade policies.

THE STORY: Why these repos? Retrofit is usually a client—lightweight, elegant, and expressive. Its annotations are a compact, machine-friendly API contract that developers love. Spring Boot is the industrial kitchen: dependable threading, observability, security, and Actuator. Tabler and AdminLTE aren’t just CSS; they’re design grammars for complex operations UIs—a language of cards, stats, tables, forms, toasts, and modals with consistent semantics. Most teams handcraft these three layers separately: client SDKs, gateways, and dashboards. We refuse that fragmentation.

THE SYNERGY: Use Retrofit interfaces as the canonical source. Spring Boot scans them at startup and generates two things: 1) a reverse proxy and aggregator (WebFlux + OkHttp via Retrofit) with circuit breaking, caching, and auth; 2) a self-describing UI schema that maps method signatures to cards, tables, forms, and charts. Tabler gives modern, breathable components; AdminLTE contributes the dense, information-rich dashboard DNA. The illicit bridge: we interpret traditional HTML attributes (href/src) as live bindings to generated gateway routes. A button with href=/api/github/issues is not mere navigation—it’s an executable graph edge. Data-* attributes decorate behavior (pagination, debounce, join), turning HTML into an orchestration DSL.

THE INNOVATION: With one contract (Retrofit), we produce a full stack: gateway, client, and operable UI. No OpenAPI necessary. No hand-rolled controllers. No Figma-to-React treadmill. This unlocks rapid integration of third-party APIs, creation of internal control planes, and ad-hoc data products. It also creates reversibility: UI elements can emit new Retrofit stubs by recording interactions, letting the system propose back the contract for permanence. The taboo connection—Retrofit-as-server + href-as-logic—shrinks the distance between idea and running system. You don’t design an admin panel; you declare an API and watch a living dashboard crystallize around it.
technical_architecture:
Core components and flow:

1) Contract Hub (Retrofit-first):
- Developers write Retrofit interfaces (Java/Kotlin). Example: interface GitHub { @GET("/repos/{o}/{r}/issues") Call<List<Issue>> issues(@Path("o") String o, @Path("r") String r, @Query("labels") String labels); }
- A Spring Boot classpath scanner locates retrofit2.http.* annotations and extracts a contract graph: HTTP method, path, parameters, return types.
- A Contract Modeler derives UI intents: GET->tables/charts, POST/PUT->forms, DELETE->confirmations, query params->filters.

2) Auto-Gateway (Spring Boot WebFlux):
- For each Retrofit method, a generated RestController (or functional router) exposes a local route (/api/{iface}/{op}).
- Retrofit instances (with OkHttp) are built per upstream with connection pooling, HTTP/2, gzip, stale-if-error, and ETag caching. Resilience4j provides circuit breakers, retries, and rate limiters.
- A custom Retrofit CallAdapter bridges to Reactor types (Mono/Flux), eliminating blocking I/O.
- Policy Pipeline: headers/auth injectors (OAuth2 client creds, API keys), request signing, and PII redaction filters. Actuator exposes metrics per-method (latency, error rate, cache hit) and logs structured via JSON.

3) Hypermedia UI Compiler (Tabler + AdminLTE):
- A small server-side pass renders a layout JSON from the contract graph. It chooses components: Issue list -> Tabler table with sticky header; POST endpoints -> AdminLTE form with validation badges; long-running jobs -> Tabler cards with spinners.
- The HTML templates are Tabler by default; AdminLTE utilities provide density, badges, and widgets for high-signal pages. A theme toggler swaps between airy (Tabler) and compact (AdminLTE) modes without changing logic.
- The illicit bridge: data-api="{iface.op}" and standard href/src attributes are bound to gateway routes. Example: a button with href="/api/github/issues?labels=bug" fetches and renders a table; img src maps to image-producing endpoints for charts. A minimal client script enhances links/forms with fetch, optimistic UI, and backpressure (debounce on filters).

4) Aggregation/Join Engine:
- A lightweight query plan language is encoded via data-join and data-map attributes. The server compiles these into fan-out Retrofit calls, merges responses, and returns a stitched view. Example: For each order, enrich with shipping status and fraud score using parallel upstream calls with a join key.
- Cache strategy: stale-while-revalidate for GET, keyed by normalized query. Conditional requests preserve upstream quotas.

5) Security and tenancy:
- Spring Security + OAuth2 client for upstreams; resource server for the UI layer. RBAC rules at the contract level (e.g., allow POST only for role operator). Per-tenant upstream credentials resolved from Vault at runtime.

6) Interfaces and protocols:
- Inputs: Retrofit interfaces (source of truth), optional OpenAPI for hints, YAML for upstream base URLs and policies.
- Outputs: /api/* REST endpoints, /ui routes serving Tabler/AdminLTE pages, /schema endpoints exposing the derived UI contract for programmatic clients.

Performance techniques:
- OkHttp connection pool tuned for long keep-alive; HTTP/2 multiplexing for high fan-out pages.
- Zero-copy passthrough for large payloads; Jackson afterburner for JSON; GZip and Brotli.
- Reactive backpressure so UI filter sliders cannot overwhelm upstreams.

Integration patterns:
- Pass-through gateway, aggregate-and-stitch, write-through with compensating actions, and event fan-out (webhooks via Boot’s reactive HTTP client). The same Retrofit contract governs all.
expected_impact:
Use cases uniquely enabled:

1) Third-party SaaS control planes in hours: Stitch Stripe disputes, GitHub issues, and Zendesk tickets into one live dashboard. Declare three Retrofit interfaces; watch tables and actions materialize with role-based controls.

2) Partner sandbox-to-production runway: Prototype an integration by sharing only Retrofit interfaces. Partners point Hypermedia Retrofit at their staging endpoints; they instantly get a working admin UI and a policy-enforced gateway. Flip base URLs to go live.

3) Compliance-grade shadow gateways: Mirror critical external APIs behind a governed proxy with audit logs, rate limits, and PII scrubbing. Operators execute actions from a generated UI without bespoke tooling.

4) Incident refraction console: Fan-out to status, logs, and error trackers via Retrofit definitions. The console prefetches correlated data with joins, showing golden signals in a single Tabler/AdminLTE pane.

5) Data product stitches: Combine catalog, pricing, and inventory APIs into a read-through endpoint powering a table and export. Cache and ETag minimize upstream load while keeping data fresh.

6) On-prem “SaaS twin”: Where cloud services are barred, host a local twin using the same contracts and fetch via bastion routes. Operators keep familiar UI, policies stay intact.

Scalability/extensibility:
- Add endpoints by adding interfaces; the UI and gateway follow. Theme-toggling and component overrides let teams brand without forking logic.

Limitations and mitigations:
- REST-first; GraphQL requires a thin adapter or schema projection. Long-running tasks need async jobs; provide polling and webhooks. Contracts without types (Object) produce generic tables; encourage DTOs or partial JSON schemas. Security requires deliberate scoping; ship sane defaults and posture checks.
innovation_analysis:
Innovation score: 8.7/10. The pivotal twist—using Retrofit’s client annotations as the authoritative server and UI generator, and interpreting href/src as executable bindings—collapses three layers into one contract without resorting to heavy code generators or bespoke design systems.

Immediate next steps:
- Build classpath scanner and Contract Modeler for retrofit2.http annotations.
- Implement a WebFlux CallAdapter and per-method policy pipeline (Resilience4j, caching, auth).
- Ship the UI Compiler that maps contract to Tabler/AdminLTE components; deliver theme toggle and data-join attributes.
- Wire Actuator metrics to a health sidebar; include latency heatmaps and error toasts.

Key metrics:
- Time-to-dashboard from a fresh Retrofit interface; p95 overhead vs upstream; cache hit ratio; operator task completion time; LoC saved compared to hand-built controllers + UI.

Essential tools:
- Spring Boot WebFlux, Retrofit + OkHttp, Resilience4j, Jackson, Tabler, AdminLTE, Spring Security, Vault (credentials), and a minimal client enhancer (fetch + backpressure).

sources.name: spring-projects/spring-boot
sources.readme_snippet:
= Spring Boot image:https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/actions/workflows/build-and-deploy-snapshot.yml/badge.svg?branch=main["Build Status", link="https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/actions/workflows/build-and-deploy-snapshot.yml?query=branch%3Amain"] image:https://img.shields.io/badge/Revved%20up%20by-Develocity-06A0CE?logo=Gradle&labelColor=02303A["Revved up by Develocity", link="https://ge.spring.io/scans?&search.rootProjectNames=Spring%20Boot%20Build&search.rootProjectNames=spring-boot-build"]

:docs: https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot
:github: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot

Spring Boot helps you to create Spring-powered, production-grade applications and services with absolute minimum fuss.
It takes an opinionated view of the Spring platform so that new and existing users can quickly get to the bits they need.

You can use Spring Boot to create stand-alone Java applications that can be started using `java -jar` or more traditional WAR deployments.
We also provide a command-line tool that runs Spring scripts.

Our primary goals are:

* Provide a radically faster and widely accessible getting started experience for all Spring development.
* Be opinionated, but get out of the way quickly as requirements start to diverge from the defaults.
* Provide a range of non-functional features common to large classes of projects (for example, embedded servers, security, metrics, health checks, externalized configuration).
* Absolutely no code generation and no requirement for XML configuration.



== Installation and Getting Started

The {docs}[reference documentation] includes detailed {docs}/installing.html[installation instructions] as well as a comprehensive {docs}/tutorial/first-application/index.html[``getting started``] guide.

Here is a quick teaser of a complete Spring Boot application in Java:

[source,java]
----
import org.springframework.boot.*;
import org.springframework.boot.autoconfigure.*;
import org.springframework.we

sources.name: square/retrofit
sources.readme_snippet:
Retrofit
========

A type-safe HTTP client for Android and Java.

For more information please see [the website][1].


Download
--------

Download [the latest JAR][2] or grab from Maven central at the coordinates `com.squareup.retrofit2:retrofit:3.0.0`.

Snapshots of the development version are available in [Sonatype's `snapshots` repository][snap].

Retrofit requires at minimum Java 8+ or Android API 21+.


R8 / ProGuard
-------------

If you are using R8 the shrinking and obfuscation rules are included automatically.

ProGuard users must manually add the options from
[retrofit2.pro][proguard file].
You might also need [rules for OkHttp][okhttp proguard] which is a dependency of this library.


License
=======

    Copyright 2013 Square, Inc.

    Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License");
    you may not use this file except in compliance with the License.
    You may obtain a copy of the License at

       http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0

    Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software
    distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
    WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
    See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
    limitations under the License.


 [1]: https://square.github.io/retrofit/
 [2]: https://search.maven.org/remote_content?g=com.squareup.retrofit2&a=retrofit&v=LATEST
 [snap]: https://s01.oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots/
 [proguard file]: https://github.com/square/retrofit/blob/master/retrofit/src/main/resources/META-INF/proguard/retrofit2.pro
 [okhttp proguard]: https://square.github.io/okhttp/r8_proguard/
 [okio proguard]: https://square.github.io/okio/#r8-proguard

sources.name: ColorlibHQ/AdminLTE
sources.readme_snippet:
# [AdminLTE - Bootstrap 5 Admin Dashboard](https://adminlte.io)

[![npm version](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/admin-lte/latest.svg)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/admin-lte)
[![Packagist](https://img.shields.io/packagist/v/almasaeed2010/adminlte.svg)](https://packagist.org/packages/almasaeed2010/adminlte)
[![cdn version](https://data.jsdelivr.com/v1/package/npm/admin-lte/badge)](https://www.jsdelivr.com/package/npm/admin-lte)
[![Discord Invite](https://img.shields.io/badge/discord-join%20now-green)](https://discord.gg/jfdvjwFqfz)
[![Netlify Status](https://api.netlify.com/api/v1/badges/1277b36b-08f3-43fa-826a-4b4d24614b3c/deploy-status)](https://app.netlify.com/sites/adminlte-v4/deploys)

**AdminLTE** is a fully responsive administration template. Based on **[Bootstrap 5](https://getbootstrap.com/)** framework and also the JavaScript plugins.
Highly customizable and easy to use. Fits many screen resolutions from small mobile devices to large desktops.

## What's New in v4.0.0-rc5

**Latest Release with Major Dependency Updates & Security Fixes** - Fresh improvements for better development experience:

- **Major Dependency Updates** - 17+ npm packages updated to latest versions
- **Security Enhancements** - Fixed 2 critical vulnerabilities (axios DoS, form-data random function)
- **Latest Tooling** - Updated to TypeScript 5.9.3, ESLint 9.37.0, Astro 5.14.4, and more
- **Bootstrap 5.3.8** - Updated to the latest stable Bootstrap release
- **ESLint 9.x Compatibility** - Removed deprecated `.eslintignore` file
- **Zero Vulnerabilities** - All security issues resolved

**Key Improvements:**
- ✅ All dependencies updated to their absolute latest versions
- ✅ Two major version bumps: cross-env 10.x and eslint-config-xo-typescript 9.x
- ✅ Enhanced security with vulnerability fixes
- ✅ Cleaner linting without deprecation warnings
- ✅ Production-ready with enhanced stability
- ✅ Faster builds with latest Rollup, Sass, and Terser

**Install the latest:**
```bash
npm install adm
